philipborlin@... wrote:

> I for one wouldn't mind seeing a bit more beef in the manual or maybe just
> a second manual for 'advanced' usage.  I am in charge of getting a test
> framework written for an application with over 200K lines of code that does
> not have a single test case yet.  Yikes!  It is very confusing about how to
> start and how to set up an application level test suite that will touch all
> the classes.  I would be willing to write about my experiences once I
> figure it out, but that may be some time.
>

Can you tell us more about this effort?  Specifically, if you had test cases for all the
code, how would that help?

In general, before touching existing code I'll write a test to create a safety net.  The
test helps me learn the behaviors of the existing code, and gives me confidence that I
can fiddle with it safely.  The test suite grows over time as more code is touched,
defects are reported, and I learn more about its intended behavior.

It sounds as if you're attempting to write tests for all the classes post-development.
I haven't had good experiences with attempting to generate test cases en masse.
Generated test code tends to be too shallow, and I miss the opportunity to learn more
about the code.

Mike
